questions.text: Nucleus pulposus is derived from ____________.
questions.solution:
Nucleus pulposus is derived from the notochord (marked as 1).

The other labelled structures are

2 - Ectoderm
3 - Endoderm
4 - Intraembryonic mesoderm

questions.text: Which of the following diseases primarily involves the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain at the level of superior colliculus is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra is seen in Parkinson's disease, also known as paralysis agitans.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease, there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Other options:

Option B: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease, but is not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

Option C: Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia. It is due to atrophy of the entorhinal cortex, located in the medial temporal lobe.

Option D: Huntington’s chorea is an autosomal dominant disorder of movement and cognition primarily involving the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen).

Related Pearl: Abnormal movements

 

 Movement Site Description Cause
Intentional tremor Cerebellum Only on activity 
  • Trauma
  • Stroke
  • Alcohol
  • Drugs
Resting tremor

Substantia nigra

Red nucleus

 Disappear on movement
  •  Parkinsonism
Hyperkinetic tremor Sympathetic overactivity  Precipitated by emotion , stress
  • Anxiety 
  • Hyperthyroidism 
Asterixis Cortex Inability to sustain a muscle contraction while performing a complex motor movement
  • Hepatic encephalopathy 
Chorea Caudate nucleus and putamen  Rapid jerky movement
  • Rheumatic chorea
  • Huntington chorea
  • Drug induced 
Hemibalismus Subthalamic nucleus Unilateral wild flinging violent movement of large proximal joints
  • Vascular>degenerative 
Athetosis Basal ganglia- Globus Pallidum Slow writhing movement involving distal joints
  • Vascular 
  • Degenerative 
  • Infiltrative

questions.text: The image below shows the insertion of transversus abdominis muscle. Identify the conjoint tendon:
questions.solution:
The structure marked C is the conjoint tendon.

The conjoint tendon is formed from the lower fibers of the internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. It is attached the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line.

Transversus Abdominis muscle:

  • Origin: Internal surface of 7th-12th costal cartilages, thoracolumbar fascia, iliac crest, connective tissue deep to lateral third of inguinal ligament.
  • Insertion: Linea Alba with aponeurosis of internal oblique, pubic crest, and pecten pubis via the conjoint tendon.

Other options:

A: Lumbar fascia
B: Transversus abdominis
D: Inguinal ligament

questions.text: Which of the following structures does the cell pointed in arrow inhibit?
questions.solution:
The cell pointed in arrow inhibit deep nuclei of cerebellum.

Image shows a histopathological section of the cerebellum. Cells marked with the arrow in the image are Purkinje cells.

Axons of Purkinje cells form the only output from cerebellar cortex and they project to the deep cerebellar nuclei(mainly dentate nucleus).

Other cells include basket, golgi and stellate cells are inhibitory interneurons. Granule cells receives excitatory inputs from moss fibres and relay onto purkinje cells to exert stimulatory effect.

questions.text: Which of the following can be responsible for Bezold-Jarisch reflex?
questions.solution:
Serotonin can be responsible for Bezold–Jarisch reflex.

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers located in the cardiopulmonary region (ex: ventricles, atria, great veins, pulmonary artery, juxtacapillary region of alveoli) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This response is called Bezold-Jarisch reflex.

Other substances that can cause Bezold–Jarisch reflex are capsaicin, phenyl biguanide, and veratridine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle?
questions.solution:
Alpha actinin is the constituent of the marked area.

The image depicts sarcomere and the arrow points towards Z-line. Alpha actinin binds actin to Z-lines.

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.


The thick filaments, which are about twice the diameter of the thin filaments, are made up of myosin; the thin filaments are made up of actin, tropomyosin, and troponin.  The thick filaments are lined up to form the A bands, whereas the array of thin filaments extends out of the A band and into the less dense staining I bands.


The lighter H bands in the center of the A bands are the regions where, when the muscle is relaxed, the thin filaments do not overlap the thick filaments.  The Z lines allow for anchoring of the thin filaments. Actinin, titin and desmin are additional structural proteins.


Titin connects Z-lines to the M line and provides the scaffolding to the sarcomere.  Desmin adds structure to Z-lines by connecting Z-line to plasma membrane.


Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second best answer.

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency results in decreased​ energy production, because TPP _______

choices.text: Is coenzyme for pyruvate and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Interferes with energy production from amino acids

questions.solution:
Thiamine deficiency results in decreased energy production because thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) is a coenzyme of pyruvate and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, which are required for the production of ATP using NADH.

Thiamine pyrophosphate is an important coenzyme in three multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase in carbohydrate metabolism.
  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle.
  • Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine and valine.

NAD is a co-factor in pyruvate and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. Hence in thiamine deficiency, there is decreased ATP production owing to reduced NADH entering into the electron transport chain.

Option A: Thiamine does not interfere in alcohol metabolism but alcohol interferes directly with the absorption of thiamine and with the synthesis of thiamine pyrophosphate.

Option B: Thiamine is also the coenzyme for transketolase in the pentose phosphate pathway (HMP shunt) but there is no ATP synthesized in this pathway.

questions.text: The magenta-colored tongue is seen in which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Magenta-colored tongue seen in vitamin B2 deficiency.

Riboflavin deficiency is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include:

  • Corneal neovascularization
  • Cheilosis or angular stomatitis (cracking or scaling of lip borders and corners of the mouth)
  • Magenta-colored tongue
  • Seborrheic dermatitis

questions.text: Of the following, which parasite’s life cycle is shown below?
questions.solution:
The life cycle shown is of clonorchis sinensis.

Clonorchis sinensis causes clonorchiasis (Asian liver fluke infection)
Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae (metacercariae).

The immature flukes after excystation in the duodenum enter the biliary ducts and differentiate into adults.
The hermaphroditic adults produce eggs which are excreted in the feces. Upon reaching fresh water the eggs are ingested by snails , which are the first intermediate hosts. The eggs hatch within the gut and differentiate first into larvae (rediae) and then into many free swimming cercariae. Cercariae encyst under the scales of certain freshwater fish which are then ingested by humans.

Clonorchiasis is endemic in China, Japan, Korea and Indochina

questions.text: Identify the egg in the picture given below
questions.solution:
The egg in the given picture indicates hookworm egg.

Eggs of both Ancylostoma Duodenale (old world hookworm) and Necator Americanus(new world hookworm) are identical.

The eggs of hookworm are :

  • Oval or elliptical
  • Colorless,
  • Not bile stained,
  • With a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane
  • Thin shell
  • Segmented ovum - 4 to 8 blastomeres
  • There is clear space between segmented ovum and egg shell.
  • Eggs float in saturated salt solution.

Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin.

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products?
questions.solution:
When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments. 

Enzymatic digestion of antibody with Papain, Pepsin and Mercaptoethanol produces fragments as follows: 

a) Papain: 2 Fab fragments and one Fc fragment
b) Pepsin: One F(ab’)2 fragment and many smaller fragments
c) Mercaptoethanol: 2 H and 2 L chains

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Histopathological image shows acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis/intercapillary glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Three renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions:
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Renal histopathology in

  • Amyloidosis: Glomerular deposits appearing as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid
  • Lupus nephritis: Immune complex deposits in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall; lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

questions.text: The histopathological slide given below is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given slide shows a row of tombstones appearance, which is classically seen in pemphigus vulgaris. 

In this condition, there is a suprabasal splitting of the epidermis leading to blister formation. The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones as shown in the histology image below.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins, desmogleins 1 and 3 expressed in the skin and mucosa.

Clinically, the patients present with ill-defined, irregular, slow-to-heal oral lesions and erosions. Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may arise on normal skin or an erythematous base. The rupture of such blisters produces painful erosions and heals without scarring.

Nikolsky's sign is positive which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing erosion.

Direct immunofluorescence is considered the most accurate confirmatory test of this condition. It shows intercellular IgG and C3 deposition on the surface of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis in normal, perilesional skin, in a characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance as seen below.

questions.text: What does the red cell distribution width (RDW) deal with ?
questions.solution:
RDW deal with anisocytosis.

When the red cells vary greatly in size, anisocytosis is said to be present.

The electronic cell counter provides an independent assessment of variability in red cell size. It measures the range of red cell volumes and reports the results as “red cell distribution width” (RDW). This value is calculated from the MCV; thus, cell width is not being measured but cell volume is.
In the presence of morphologic anisocytosis, RDW (normally 11–14%) increases to 15–18%.
In patients with microcytic anaemia, the differential diagnosis is generally between iron deficiency and thalassemia. In thalassemia, the small red cells are generally of uniform size with a normal small RDW. In iron deficiency, the size variability and the RDW are large.

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactant?
questions.solution:
Albumin is a negative acute phase reactant while haptoglobin, ferritin and C-reactive protein are positive acute phase reactants.

Acute phase reactants are classified as positive and negative based on whether their levels decrease or increase in inflammatory states.

Markers such as CRP, inflammatory cytokines(positive acute phase reactants) are elevated while markers such as albumin, fetuin(negative acute phase reactants) decrease.

Related Pearl: Acute phase reactants and their functions

"Positive" acute-phase proteins:

Protein

Immune system function

C-reactive protein

Opsonin on microbes

Serum amyloid P component

Opsonin

Serum amyloid A

Recruitment of immune cells to inflammatory sites

Induction of enzymes that degrade extracellular matrix

Complement factors

Opsonization, lysis, and clumping of target cells; Chemotaxis

Mannan-binding lectin

Mannan-binding lectin pathway of complement activation

Fibrinogen, prothrombin, factor VIII,
von Willebrand factor

Coagulation factors, trapping invading microbes in blood clots.
Some cause chemotaxis, Fibrinogen binds to red cells and induce rouleaux formation

Plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1)

Prevents the degradation of blood clots by inhibiting plasminogen 

Alpha 2-macroglobulin

Inhibitor of coagulation by inhibiting thrombin

Inhibitor of fibrinolysis by inhibiting plasmin

Ferritin

Binding iron, inhibiting microbe iron uptake

Hepcidin

Stimulates the internalization of ferroportin, preventing release of iron bound by ferritin within intestinal enterocytes and macrophages

Ceruloplasmin

Oxidizes iron, facilitating for ferritin, inhibiting microbe iron uptake

Haptoglobin

Binds hemoglobin, inhibiting microbe iron uptake

Orosomucoid
(Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein, AGP)

Steroid carrier

Alpha 1-antitrypsin

Serpin, downregulates inflammation

Alpha 1-antichymotrypsin

Serpin, downregulates inflammation

Thrombopoietin

Thrombocytosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the development of T lymphocyte?
questions.solution:
PAX5 is a transcription factor required for B cell development not T cell development.
CD34 is marker of hematopoietic stem cell.
Tdt - Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is a specialized DNA polymerase, that is expressed only in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts.
CD1a - CD1 are common to all T Cells. CD1 is also seen in langerhans type of dendritic cell.

questions.text: Which of the following can alter the gene expression by methylation and acetylation but not change the gene sequence?
questions.solution:
Epigenetics is defined as heritable changes in gene expression that are not caused by alteration in gene sequence.
It means “above genetics” and refers to the fact that gene regulatory mechanisms do not change the underlying regulated DNA sequence, but rather simply the expression patterns of the DNA.


Epigenetic mechanisms play a key role in establishment, maintenance, and reversibility of transcriptional states. A key feature is that the controlled transcriptional on/off states can be maintained through multiple rounds of cell division. This observation indicates there must be robust mechanisms to maintain and stably propagate these epigenetic states.


Histone Methylation Mostly Makes DNA Mute.
Histone Acetylation: Relaxes DNA coiling, allowing for transcription. Histone Acetylation makes DNA Active.

questions.text: If the RB gene is hypophosphorylated, which of the following will happen?

choices.text: Cell cycle will stop at G2.
Cell cycle will stop at G1.
There will be no effect on cell cycle as RB gene phosphorylation is not needed.
The cell cycle progresses and cell divides.

questions.solution:
If the Rb gene is hypophosphorylated, then cell cycle will stop at G1.

Rb is a cell-cycle regulator because it binds to and inactivates a transcription factor (E2F) necessary for the transcription of certain genes necessary for the progression from G1 to S phase.

The phosphorylation of Rb results in the release of E2F, whereby gene transcription activation ensues and cell-cycle progression takes place.

Remember:

  • Rb gene in active hypophosphorylated state: Cell cycle arrest
  • Rb gene in inactive hyperphosphorylated state: transcriptional activation and cell cycle progression.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. (intense pink color)

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome. It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

  • Light microscopy: diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane are best seen with silver stains.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes
 
Image: The silver stain of the glomerulus highlights the proteinaceous basement membranes in black. There are characteristic "spikes" of basement membrane between the immune deposits of membranous nephropathy. The black basement membrane material shown here appears as projections in the capillary loops. 

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

 Light microscopy Fluorescence microscopy

Electron microscopy

Nephritic syndrome:

Postinfectious glomerulo-nephritis

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgG and C3 in glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, 

Granular IgA in some cases

 

Subepithelial humps Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages

Goodpasture syndrome

 Extracapillary proliferation with crescents; necrosis  Linear IgG and C3; fibrin in crescents

Linear deposits along the basement membrane. 

Disruptions in GBM

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

 Focal mesangial proliferative glomerulo-nephritis; mesangial widening  IgA ± IgG, IgM, and C3 in mesangium Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits 

Alport syndrome

 Normal Negative Basket-weave appearance of GBM

Nephrotic syndrome:

Membranous  nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

 

Subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes), effacement of podocyte 

Minimal change disease

Normal; lipid in tubules

 Negative 

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte 

Focal segmental glomerulo-sclerosis  (FSGS)

Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis

 Occasional C3 and IgM deposits in the sclerotic areas and the mesangium.

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte 

Epithelial denudation.

Nephrito-nephrotic syndrome:   

Membrano-proliferative glomerulo-nephritis

(MPGN) type I

Mesangial proliferative pattern of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3, C1q, C4 deposits 

IgG deposits

Subendothelial deposits

Dense-deposit disease (MPGN type II)

Mesangial proliferative  pattern of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3 deposits;

No C1q and C4 deposits

No IgG deposits

 

Intramembranous Dense deposits

Fibrillary glomerulo-nephritis

  

Membrano-proliferative or mesangio-proliferative patterns

 IgG4 and C3  Fibrillar deposits in the mesangium and capillary walls

 

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

questions.text: A 25 year old female came to opd 1 year after delivery. She was treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. Now she was pale and her Hb was 5% and reticulocyte count was 9%. Her corrected retic count is: (Take normal Hb as 15g/dl)
questions.solution:
Corrected Reticulocyte is calculated as= (Actual hb/Normal hb) x Reticulocyte %

According to values given in this question,

Corrected reticulocyte count=5 x 9/15 = 3%.

Note: Normal Hb is taken as 15g/dl

questions.text: Which of the following Immunohistochemistry marker is used in Cyclin D1 negative Mantle cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
SOX11 is used in Cyclin D1 negative Mantle cell lymphoma. Mutation of SOX11 is associated with worse prognosis in mantle cell lymphoma.

Other options are not associated with mantle cell lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an idiosyncratic reaction of carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Blurred vision is not an idiosyncratic reaction of carbamazepine.

Idiosyncratic blood dyscrasias with carbamazepine, include fatal cases of aplastic anaemia and agranulocytosis. The most common idiosyncratic reaction is an erythematous skin rash. It can rarely cause Steven Johnson Syndrome.

questions.text: Among the following what can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy?
questions.solution:
Aminocaproic acid is a clinically useful inhibitor of fibrinolysis. Heparin and oral anticoagulant drugs do not affect the fibrinolytic mechanism.

Streptokinase is a fibrinolytic agent.

Schematic representation of fibrinolytic system:

Regulation of fibrinolytic system is useful in therapeutics.

Increased fibrinolysis is effective therapy for thrombotic diseases.

Conversly, decreased fibrinolysis protects clots from lysis and reduces the bleeding of hemostatic failure.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy came with complaints of 6 patches on back and on left arm that were hypopigmented with the loss of sensation. Which of the following is the treatment for this case?

choices.text: Rifampicin (450 mg)+ Dapsone (50mg) + clofazimine (150 mg) monthly and 50 mg daily
Rifampicin (450mg) + Dapsone (50mg) + clofazimine (150 mg) monthly and 50 mg alternate days
Rifampicin (600mg) + Dapsone (150mg) + clofazimine (300 mg) monthly and 50 mg daily

questions.solution:
The presence of 6 patches on back and on left arm that were hypopigmented with loss of sensation suggest multibacillary leprosy.

According to the NLEP recommended multidrug therapy regimens for Hansen disease Multibacillary (LL,BL,BB) in pediatric patients

Monthly
(SUPERVISED)		 Daily
(SELF ADMINISTERED)
Rifampicin 450mg Dapsone 50mg
Clofazimine 150mg

Clofazimine 50mg

The duration of therapy is 12 months. In multibacillary leprosy among children aged 10-14 years, Clofazimine is administered daily.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Ridley Jopling Classification in Leprosy

  TT (Tuberculoid Leprosy) BT (Borderline Tuberculoid) BB (Borderline) BL(Borderline Lepromatous) LL (Lepromatous Leprosy)

defined hypopigmented macule(s) or plaque(s) with elevated sloping borders 'saucer right side up' lesion. Asymmetrical distribution.

questions.text: In a middle aged diabetic with CKD stage 5 , which of the following can  be given safely without altering the dose?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin can be given safely without altering the dose for this patient.

Linagliptin is a Dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) Inhibitor. It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy with other drugs when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated.

Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that is eliminated by a hepatobiliary route. Hence no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure. Other DPP-4 inhibitors (sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin) show renal elimination.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Oseltamivir  as an antiviral agent is:

choices.text: Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA polymerase

questions.solution:
Mechanism of action of Oseltamivir as an antiviral agent is neuraminidase inhibition.

Oseltamivir carboxylate is a transition state analog of sialic acid  that is a potent selective inhibitor of influenza  A and B virus neuraminidases.

Drug of choice in viral diseases:

Measels, Respiratory syncytial virus, viral hemorrhagic fever:Ribavirin

Seasonal influenza ,avian influenza:Oseltamivir

Oseltamivir resistant influenza:zanamivir

Prion disease:Flupirtine

Herpes simplex ,varicella :acyclovir

Acute herpes zooster: valacyclovir

Cytomegalovirus retinitis : Gancicyclovir

questions.text: Observe the following curves, which of the following is true statement about sensitivity and specificity when the curve changes from green to pink?
questions.solution:
The true statement is both sensitivity and specificity increase.

Sensitivity: Proportion of all people with disease who test positive, or the probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.
Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) or Sensitivity = 1 – false-negative rate

Specificity: Proportion of all people without disease who test negative, or the probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.
Specificity= TN / (TN + FP) or specificity= 1 – false-positive rate

In this question, switching from green to red increases number of true positive and true negatives and decreases false positive and negatives.
Hence leading to increased sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed to find the cause of death of a person brought dead to the casualty and it showed a fracture of the thyroid cartilage and bruising around the neck. The cause of death is?
questions.solution:
Both bruising around the neck and the fracture of the thyroid cartilage are findings seen in throttling. Throttling/manual strangulation is when bare hands are used to compress the neck and strangulate.


Mechanism of death:

  • Occlusion of blood vessels supplying blood to the brain (carotid arteries).
  • Occlusion to airway probably plays a minor role if any, in causing death
  • Carotid sinus pressure may result in vagus nerve stimulation, resulting in cardiac arrest (vagal inhibition)

Autopsy findings:

  • Bruising of neck: due to the grasping of the neck by the assailant.
  • Abrasions on the neck: fingernail marks from assailant or victim
  • Fracture of thyroid cartilage
  • Inward fracture of greater cornu of the hyoid bone.

questions.text: Identify the test shown below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows tonometry.

This is a dynamic contour tonometer (Pascal).

Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings are not affected by central corneal thickness.

Pascal is the tonometer of choice for post LASIK corneas.

questions.text: A patient came to the Opthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Suprachoroidal haemorrhage will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.

Maculopathy is common in eyes developing hypotony, defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg. The most common cause is excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery.

Other causes include:

  • Trauma (cyclodialysis cleft, penetrating injury)
  • Chronic uveitis
  • Retinal detachment.
  • Systemic causes of hypotony (usually bilateral) include dehydration, hyperglycaemia in uncontrolled diabetes, uraemia and treatment with hyperosmotic agents or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false?

choices.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position
The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle
Coagulopathy is not an absolute contraindication

questions.solution:
The above image shows a Lumbar puncture needle. Coagulopathy is an absolute contraindication.

Absolute contraindications for lumbar puncture include:

  • Thrombocytopenia or other bleeding diathesis (including ongoing anticoagulant therapy).
  • Possible raised intracranial pressure.
  • Suspected spinal epidural abscess.

questions.text: A patient presented with hair loss and itching of the scalp along with mild discharge. Which of the following is useful for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows tinea capitis, which presents with a well demarcated scaly patch in which hair shafts are broken off just above the skin resulting in alopecia. KOH mount is useful for the depicted condition.

The disease may vary from scaling with minimal hair loss to discrete patches with “black dots” (broken infected hair) to boggy plaque with pustules (kerion).

Diagnosis: If in doubt, scrapings should from the edge of a lesion and transferred to a slide, to which KOH is added and examined under the microscope for the presence of hyphae.

Left image is a 10x objective showing KOH mount from scrapings of a lesion.
Right image is a 40x objective showing hyphae.

questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above case, the probable diagnosis is Atopic dermatitis.

Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterised by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis or eczema.

The etiology is only partially defined, but there is a clear genetic predisposition. A characteristic defect is impaired epidermal barrier. In many patients a mutation in gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum) is responsible. The lesions are distributed in the flexural aspects.(as shown in the image).

Patients may display many immunoregulatory abnormalities, including increased IgE synthesis, increased serum IgE levels, delayed type hypersensitivity reactions.

Clinical features:

  • Pruritus and scratching
  • Course marked by exacerbations and remissions
  • Lesions typical of eczematous dermatitis
  • Personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, food allergy, eczema)
  • Clinical course more than 6 weeks
  • Lichenification of skin

questions.text: Of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest X-Ray except
questions.solution:
The above x-ray is characteristic of Transposition of Great Arteries (egg on a string appearance). Findings that can be seein TGA are narrow vascular pedicle, right atrial enlargement, normal to increased pulmonary blood flow, but not pulmonary venous hypertension.

The above X-Ray shows a heart which appears globular due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg. The superior mediastinum appears narrow which gives the appearance of an egg-on-a-string, which is characteristic of Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA).

questions.text: Which is a mood stabiliser with an anti-suicidal role?
questions.solution:
Lithium is a mood stabilizer with an antisuicidal role.

Maintenance treatment with lithium has shown to decrease the rate of suicide in mood disorders. Lithium was found to be better than other mood stabilizers such as carbamazepine, lamotrigine, and valproate.

Other uses of lithium in depression:

Recurrent depression with a cyclic pattern is controlled by either lithium or imipramine. Lithium is also used to augment standard antidepressant response in acute major depression in those patients who have had an inadequate response to monotherapy.

questions.text: Identify the  name of the instrument given below:
questions.solution: The image shows bone holding forceps.

questions.text: While volunteering in an orphanage that takes care of disabled kids, you notice the typical hand-knee gait of polio in a child. He walks by putting his right hand on his right lower thigh while stepping forward. Which of the following muscle weakness is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Polio commonly affects the quadriceps, and weakness of the quadriceps leads to the buckling (bending) of the knee while walking or bearing weight on the leg. So, in order to walk, the person has to prevent the buckling of the knee by supporting with the hand, producing a hand-knee gait.

Examination findings in paralytic polio:

A. In the early stage

  • Asymmetric motor paralysis - involvement of affected muscles is haphazard. No associated sensory loss.
  • Commonly affects the lower limbs
  • Most common muscle affected - Quadriceps, although it is most often partially paralyzed
  • Most common muscle to undergo complete paralysis - Tibialis anterior
  • The most affected muscle in the hand - Opponens pollicis
  • Bulbar/bulbospinal polio - It is a rare but life-threatening disease affecting the motor neurons of the medulla and resulting in the involvement of the respiratory and cardiovascular centers, which may cause death.

B. In the late-stage

  • Weakness, wasting, and deformity of the limbs
  • At the hip-flexion-abduction-external rotation
  • At the knee, flexion deformity is common; in severe cases, there is triple deformity: flexion, posterior subluxation, and external rotation
  • At the foot, the commonest deformity is equino-varus. Other deformities - equinovalgus, calcaneo-valgus, and calcaneo-varus
  • In the upper limb: affects the shoulder and elbow, hand muscles are spared.

questions.text: March fracture is seen following stress in ____ of second metatarsal
questions.solution:
This question is about stress fracture of the 2nd metatarsal which is called March fracture.
This is a controversial question. We have chosen Neck as the right answer, since only one option can be chosen.

What various sources say:

  • Campbell orthopedics 13/e says, " patients often note the gradual onset of pain directly over the second metatarsal neck region."
  • Uptodate says, " A disproportionate number of stress fractures occur in the second metatarsal shaft, especially at the neck."
  • Grays anatomy 41/e says, "  Metatarsals are miniature long bones and have a shaft, proximal base and distal head."

This question is controversial because according to Gray’s anatomy 41/e, the metatarsal bones do not have a neck. But when we have a look at uptodate, things start to get clear. Neck is part of the shaft and is the most common site for fracture. This is also confirmed by Campbell orthopedics. As this is an orthopedics question the best answer is neck of the metatarsal. The best answer to the question is in the following order:

Neck of the shaft > Neck > Shaft

March fracture is the neck of the shaft fracture of 2nd and 3rd metatarsal resulting from long, continued or often repeated stress like prolonged walking or running in people not accustomed to it. Thus it may occur in army recruits freshly committed to marching hence the name March Fracture.

It heals spontaneously , so its treatment is symptomatic.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with PIH was being monitored with bed rest in supine position. Which of the following is a complication of the below representation?
questions.solution:
Supine vena cava syndrome is the complication of the given representation. The image shows compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus which can sometimes lead to supine hypotension.

During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the great vessels against the hard spine, when the patient is in the supine position. Of the two vessels, the vena cava is compressed, but the aorta, owing to its structure is relatively resistant.

Normally, the vena cava compression results in opening up collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygous veins but in some cases, when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed resulting in hypotension, tachycardia, and syncope and is called supine vena cava syndrome.

The normal blood pressure is quickly restored by turning the patient to the lateral position.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman came to OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3 year old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score/formula. G=gravid, P= para:
questions.solution:
The obstetric score is G4P1A2L1.

Gravida and para refer to pregnancies and not to babies.
Gravida: Total number of pregnancies including the present one.
Para: Total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability, which is 28 weeks in India.


As such, a woman who delivers twins in the first pregnancy is still a gravida 1 and para 1. A pregnant woman with a previous history of 2 abortions and 1 term delivery can be expressed as 4th Gravida but primipara.


It is customary in clinical practice to summarise the past obstetric history by 2 digits

First digit: Number of viable births
Second digit: Number of abortions
Both digits connected with a “+” sign affixing the letter P.
Thus, P1+2 denotes patient had 1 viable birth and 2 abortions.


In some centres, it is expressed by 4digits connected by dashes, P(A-B-C-D)
A: Number of term pregnancies (37-42 weeks)
B: Number of preterm pregnancies (28 to less than 37 weeks)
C: Number of miscarriages (less than 28 weeks)
D: Number of children alive at present.

questions.text: The partogram is plotted in regular intervals after _ cm dilatation:
questions.solution:
The partograph is plotted in regular intervals after 4 cm dilatation.

In a partograph, the labor process is divided into

  1. The latent phase ends when cervix dilated up to 4 cm
  2. The active phase begins with cervical dilatation of ≥6 cm and ends at 10 cm dilatation at the rate of 1 cm/hour.

The latent phase of labor is slow and extremely variable, while the active phase of labor is fairly predictable in terms of duration. Even though the active phase of labor is from more than 6cm dilatation, partograph is marked from 4 cm dilatation.

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen?
questions.solution:
Fetal alcohol syndrome is associated with microcephaly rather than macrocephaly.

  • High levels of alcohol ingestion during pregnancy can be damaging to embryonic and fetal development.
  • The presence of at least one of the below characteristics is defined as fetal alcohol syndrome:
  •  Growth restriction before and/or after birth
  • Facial anomalies: small palpebral fissures, indistinct or absent philtrum, epicanthic folds, flattened nasal bridge, short length of nose, thin upper lip, lowset and unparallel ears, retarded midfacial development.
  • CNS dysfunction: Microcephaly, mental retardation, abnormal neurobehavioral development (attention deficit with hyperactivity)

Other features:

  • Incomplete holoprosencephaly
  • Agenesis of corpus callosum and the cerebellar vermis.
  • Cardiac anomalies :VSD>ASD ,tetralogy of fallot.

questions.text: A 3 month old male child came with history of fever and respiratory distress. Suspecting pneumonia, chest X ray was ordered. Which of the following is most likely organism?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows pneumatoceles (air filled cysts within lung parenchyma), these commonly occur in staphylococcus pneumonia.

Pneumonia caused by Staphylococcus may be primary or secondary after a viral infection such as influenza. Common symptoms and signs include high fever, abdominal pain, tachypnoea, dyspnoea and localised or diffuse bronchopneumonia or lobar disease.

S. aureus often causes a necrotizing pneumonitis that may be associated with the early development of empyema, pneumatocele,pyopneumothorax and bronchopleural fistulas.

Note: Pneumatocoele can also be caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, E. coli, group A streptococci, Klebsiella pneumoniae, etc.  But Staphylococcus aureus is most common.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty ward with high fever and pain abdomen.  He had a history of bloody diarrhea for several months. The abdominal X-ray image obtained is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is toxic megacolon.

The X-ray image shows a dilated loop of the transverse colon. The history of bloody diarrhea since many days is highly suggestive of ulcerative colitis. Sudden onset of fever, abdominal pain with dilated loops of bowel in a patient of ulcerative colitis is highly suggestive of toxic megacolon.

A plain abdominal X-ray film may indicate the severity of ulcerative colitis in the acute setting and is particularly valuable in demonstrating the development of toxic megacolon.
Feces are present only in parts that are normal or only mildly inflamed. Mucosal islands can sometimes be seen. Small bowel loops in the right lower quadrant maybe a sign of severe disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was brought to the casualty ward with a history of road traffic accident (RTA) and head trauma.  Her eye opens to pain, moans, can localize limb towards the pain stimulus on the left hand and away from the pain stimulus on the right hand and both the legs in extended posture. Calculate her GCS.
questions.solution:
The GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale) of this patient is E2V2M5, which comes to a total score of 9.
E2-Eye opens to pain
V2-Moans
M5-Localizes to pain on the left hand (the score represents the best performance elicited, which would be localizing towards the pain stimulus)

Revised Glasgow coma scale for head injury:

Minimum GCS is 3, maximum GCS is 15.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 40 year old female with burns over her abdomen, both limbs and back and presented after 8 hours. Which of the following is the formula for calculation of fluid infusion?

choices.text: 2 ml/kg X %TBSA for the next 16 hours
5 ml/kg X %TSBA for the next 16 hours
4 ml/kg X %TSBA for first 8 hours then 2 ml/kg X %TBSA for next 16 hours
4 ml/kg X%TSBA for the next 16 hours

questions.solution:
Fluid resuscitation in burns:

According to ATLS 10th edition, 2018, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA.

First 8 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)
Next 16 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)

For a patient presenting 8 hours after sustaining thermal burns, the total volume using resuscitation formula should be given in the next 16 hours i.e; 2 mL/kg × % TBSA in the next 16 hours while maintaining target urine output of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults.

In adults, urine output should be maintained between 30 and 50 cc/hr to minimize potential over-resuscitation.

 

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

Total percentage of the burnt area is calculated clinically using the rule of nines.

questions.text: A 25 year old patient presented with neck swelling which moves with deglutition as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is thyroglossal cyst.

The above question describes a swelling which moves with deglutition. Classically, swellings associated with the thyroid move with deglutition. Goitre and thyroglossal cyst, move with deglutition. In this question, only thyroglossal cyst is given, so this is the answer.

The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. Thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of the track of thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline.

Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion , and it indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Although they often occur in children they may also present in adults, even as late as 6th or 7th decade.

Treatment:

Sistrunk’s operation

Excision of the whole thyroglossal tract , involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum together with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: What is not a feature of Myasthenia Gravis among the following?
questions.solution:
Absent deep tendon reflex is not a feature of myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. Reflexes are normal in Myasthenia gravis.
The underlying defect is a decrease in the number of available acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at neuromuscular junction due to an antibody mediated autoimmune attack.

Clinical features:

  • Weakness increases during repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep.
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to weakness of palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Bulbar weakness
  • Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetric
  • Deep tendon reflexes are preserved

questions.text: A patient came to the casualty after a RTA with fracture of femur. On 3rd day of admission he developed sudden breathlessness. Which of the following is the most common cause
questions.solution:
History of sudden onset breathlessness on day 3rd of admission after femur fracture should raise suspicion of fat embolism(fracture femur + breathlessness after 48 hours: fat embolism). Considering all the options given in this question, fat embolism is the appropriate answer.

Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of the long bone or other major trauma.

The pathogenesis can be explained by 2 events

  • Release of free fatty acids by action of lipases on the neutral fats
  • Actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules

Clinical features:

  • Early signs are fever and tachycardia
  • Presenting features are 2 types
  • Cerebral type: drowsy, restless, disoriented
  • Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia
  • Other features: petechial rash in front of neck/ anterior axillary fold/ chest/ conjunctiva


Classic triad: dyspnea/tachypnea + confusion/disorientation + Petechial rash

Diagnosis:

Gurds criterion for fat embolism:

Major criteria:

  • Petechiae
  • Pao2 <60mmhg
  • Pulmonary edema
  • CNS depression

Minor criteria include tachycardia, fever, anaemia, thrombocytopenia, fat globules in sputum, fat globules in urine(Gurd test), Increasing ESR, retinal emboli.
Diagnosis: 1 major + 4 minor criteria

X-Ray chest shows patchy pulmonary infiltration (snow storm appearance)

Treatment:

  • Respiratory support(O2 is the only therapeutic tool of proven benefit)
  • Heparinization(increases lipoprotein lipase activity)
  • Intravenous low molecular weight dextran
  • Corticosteroids: To avoid pneumonitis
  • IV 5% dextrose solution(decreases free fatty acid production) with 5% alcohol(vasodilator and lipolytic effect) helps emulsification of fat globules.

questions.text: A middle aged man presented with frontal bossing, a large tongue and he had spade shaped hands. Which of the following tests will you do for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The question describes a middle-aged man with frontal bossing, a large tongue and spade-shaped hands, this is highly suggestive of acromegaly. Insulin-like growth factor(IGF-1) levels are used for diagnosis of acromegaly.

Acromegaly is the clinical syndrome that results from excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH).

Clinical features of Acromegaly are:

  • Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness
  • Increased shoe or glove size, ring tightening
  • Characteristic coarse facial features-frontal bossing, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, widened space between the lower incisor teeth, and a large fleshy nose.
  • Hyperhidrosis & oily skin
  • A deep and hollow-sounding voice
  • Arthropathy, kyphosis and carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Proximal muscle weakness and fatigue
  • Acanthosis nigricans and skin tags.
  • Generalized visceromegaly occurs, including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, and thyroid gland enlargement.

Diagnosis:

Screening test: Insulin-like growth factor(IGF-1) levels are measures. GH is also increased but interpretation of GH values is unreliable because of pulsatility in GH secretion.
Confirmatory test: GH suppression test: Demonstrating the failure of GH suppression to <0.4 μg/L within 1–2 h of an oral glucose load (75 g).
